titleStmt.title: Performance Analysis of Multi-antenna Hybrid Satellite-Terrestrial Relay Networks in the Presence of Interference

analytic.title: Performance Analysis of Multi-antenna Hybrid Satellite-Terrestrial Relay Networks in the Presence of Interference

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The integration of cooperative transmission into satellite networks is regarded as an effective strategy to increase the energy efficiency as well as the coverage of satellite communications. This paper investigates the performance of an amplify-and-forward (AF) hybrid satellite-terrestrial relay network (HSTRN), where the links of the two hops undergo Shadowed-Rician and Rayleigh fading distributions, respectively. By assuming that a single antenna relay is used to assist the signal transmission between the multi-antenna satellite and multiantenna mobile terminal, and multiple interferers corrupt both the relay and destination, we first obtain the equivalent end-toend signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) of the system. Then, an approximate yet very accurate closed-form expression for the ergodic capacity of the HSTRN is derived. The analytical lower bound expressions are also obtained to efficiently evaluate the outage probability (OP) and average symbol error rate (ASER) of the system. Furthermore, the asymptotic OP and ASER expressions are developed at high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) to reveal the achievable diversity order and array gain of the considered HSTRN. Finally, simulation results are provided to validate of the analytical results, and show the impact of various parameters on the system performance.

obstacles and shadowing between the satellite and terrestrial user may result in the masking effect, which makes a line of sight (LOS) communication difficult to be maintained [1]. Relay transmissions, in which a relay forwards the received signal from a source to an intended destination, has attracted significant attention in various wireless communication systems, since they can increase reliability and throughput under given power or bandwidth [2] constraints. A novel network architecture referred as the hybrid satellite terrestrial relay network (HSTRN) has been proposed to exploit both advantages to significantly enhance system performance (e.g. [3]).

div.head: A. Background and Motivation
div.p: Substantial effort has been devoted to investigating the performance of HSTRNs by employing various relay protocols, such as amplify-and-forward (AF) and decode-and-forward (DF). By assuming maximal ratio combining (MRC) at the destination, the authors of [4] studied the average symbol error rate (ASER) of HSTRN with an AF relaying protocol, and an AF-based hybrid satellite-terrestrial free space optical (FSO) cooperative system was studied in [5], in which the asymptotic ASER behavior was investigated. In [6], the authors have considered the applicability of multi-satellite multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communications by employing dualsatellite 2×2 MIMO channels where each satellite is equipped with a single antenna. Moreover, the outage probability (OP) performance comparison of HSTRNs with fixed relaying (FR) and selection relaying (SR) protocols was presented in [7]- [8].

The research in [4]- [8] was mainly focused on scenarios where all the nodes are equipped with a single antenna. However, since multi-antenna techniques exhibit a significant advantage in achieving high system capacity and energy efficiency [9]- [11], cases involving satellites with multiple antennas have recently received significant attention [12]. When channel state information (CSI) is available, a practical strategy among a variety of multi-antenna techniques is beamforming (BF) due to its low implementation complexity [9]. The work of [13] has analyzed the performance of multiple antenna satellite communication systems in one-hop scenarios, and derived expressions for the ergodic capacity, OP and ASER. Extensions of [13] to cases with estimation errors at the destination can be found in [14]. Since relay transmissions have proved to be an effective approach in enhancing the throughput and coverage of satellite communications, the authors of [15]- [20] have investigated the performance of relay-based multiple antenna HSTRNs with beamforming (BF). Specifically, in [15], the performance of a multiple antenna HSTRN with both AF and DF protocols has been analyzed by deriving exact closed-form expressions for OP and ASER. In [16], the performance of beamforming in AF-based HSTRNs with multiple antenna terrestrial relays and destinations has been studied, and both analytical and asymptotic ASER expressions have been derived. Moreover, [17] has investigated DF-based satellite relaying with a multi-antenna terrestrial source and destination, and extensions to the AF-based scenarios can be found in [18]. By considering two-way HSTRNs with multiple antennas at the relay, an approximate ASER expression based on moment generating functions (MGF) was presented in [19]. The work of [20] investigated the effect of antenna correlation on the performance of multiple antenna HSTRNs and provided analytical expressions for OP, ASER, and ergodic capacity.

Although the aforementioned research has significantly improved the performance and benefits of HSTRNs, this work has assumed the ideal case of no co-channel interference (CCI), which is unrealistic in practical wireless systems. In recent years, a great deal of research has focused on the performance of conventional terrestrial systems in the presence of CCI over Rayleigh or Nakagami-m fading channels [21]- [23]. Due to the reuse of spectrum resources in practice, the major challenge facing hybrid satellite-terrestrial networks is the problem of interference from inter-component and/or intracomponent [24] networks. While [25] first investigated the ASER performance of HSTRNs with CCI at the destination for the single antenna scenario, the ergodic capacity, OP, and ASER have not been studied in the case that the satellite and terrestrial user have multiple antennas with CCI corrupting both the relay and destination nodes.

div.head: B. Contributions and Novelty
div.p: In this paper, we consider a multi-antenna AF HSTRN with multiple interferers at both the terrestrial relay and destination, where the source-relay link undergoes Shadowed-Rician fading while the relay-destination link experiences Rayleigh fading. By applying maximal ratio transmission (MRT) at the source and maximal ratio combining (MRC) at the destination, the equivalent end-to-end output signalto-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) of the system is first obtained, then analytical expressions as well as asymptotic results are derived to evaluate the system performance. The detailed contributions of this paper are outlined as follows:

• We present a new analytical expression for the ergodic capacity of the hybrid system, which is applicable to cases involving an arbitrary number of interferers and antennas. • Tight analytical expressions for the OP and ASER are derived, which can efficiently evaluate the system performance. We consider multiple-antenna scenarios with the presence of CCI, while [4]- [6] only considered single antenna scenarios without the presence of CCI. Although [14] considered the multiple antenna case, it ignored the CCI in the system performance analysis.
denote the Meijer-G functions of two variables [27].

div.head: II. SYSTEM MODEL
div.p: Consider an AF HSTRN in which a geostationary satellite (S) communicates with a terrestrial destination (D) via a terrestrial relay (R). Here, the direct link between S and D is assumed to be unavailable due to heavy shadowing. The communication occurs during two time phases. During the first time phase, the satellite carries out transmit BF with weight vector w 1 (N s × 1) and sends the signal x (t) to R through the fading channel h 1 (N s × 1). Meanwhile, the signal received by R is corrupted by
div.formula: I 1 co-channel interferers {s 1,i (t)} I1 i=1
div.p: with an average power of {P 1,i } I 1 i=1 . As such, the received signal at R can be written as
div.formula: y r (t) = P s w H 1 h 1 x (t)+ I 1 i=1 P 1,i g 1,i s 1,i (t)+n 1 (t) , (1
div.p: where P s denotes the transmit power at S, x (t) is the transmit signal with E |x (t)| 2 = 1 and n 1 (t) is zero mean additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) at R satisfying
In addition, g 1,i is the channel coefficient for the i-th interference-relay link, and is assumed to be drawn from an independently and identically distributed (i.i.d) complex Gaussian distribution.
During the second time phase, R first amplifies the received signal by a variable gain factor G as
and then sends it to D through the fading channel h 2 (N d × 1).

Under the condition that the destination is corrupted by I 2 interferers with average powers {P 2,j } I2 j=1 , and that a receive BF weight vector w 2 (N d × 1) is used, the output signal at D is given by
div.formula: y d (t)= w H 2 P r Gh 2 y r (t)+ I2 j=1 P 2,j g 2,j s 2,j (t)+n 2 (t) , (3
div.p: where P r is the transmit power at R,
div.formula: n 2 (t) is AWGN at D obeying n 2 (t) ∼ N C 0, σ 2 2 I N d , {s 2,j (t)} I2 j=1
div.p: represents the interference signal with each obeying E |s 2,j (t)| 2 = 1, and g 2,j is the channel vector for the j-th interference-destination link satisfying g 2,j ∼ N C 0,
div.formula: I N d .
div.p: Assuming that perfect CSI is available at either S or D, MRT and MRC can be adopted 1 , in which case w 1 = h 1 / h 1 F and w 2 = h 2 / h 2 F . By using (1) and ( 2) for (3), after some algebraic manipulations, the output SINR at D can be expressed as

div.formula: I1 i=1 P 1,i g 1,i 2 σ 2 1 Δ = I1 i=1 γ3,i g 1,i 2 , Γ 2 = γ 2 /(γ 4 +1) with γ 2 = P r h 2 2 F σ 2 2 Δ = γ2 h 2 2

div.p: F . Here, γ1 , γ2 , γ3,i , and γ4,j denote the average SNRs of each link.

In order to analyze the performance of the HSTRN, we first introduce some known results about the statistical properties of wireless fading channels, and then provide a detailed derivation of the theoretical formulas for the ergodic capacity, OP, and ASER of the considered system.

div.head: III. PRELIMINARY RESULTS
div.p: Satellite-terrestrial links are usually modeled by composite fading distributions to describe more accurately the amplitude fluctuation of the signal envelope [18]. Although some mathematical models, such as Loo, Barts-Stutzman, and Karasawa et al., have been presented to describe the satellite channel, the Shadowed-Rician model proposed in [28] is a popular one, which provides a significantly less computational burden than other channel models. The channel vector h 1 with i.i.d Shadowed-Rician fading distribution is described as h 1 = 1 In the presence of co-channel interference, the zero-forcing (ZF) or minimum mean-square error (MMSE) beamforming schemes can achieve a better performance. However, they require CSI for the interfering links, which results in significant implementation complexity. On the contrary, the MRC scheme adopted in this paper only requires CSI for the satellite-relay link, which is easier to obtain. h1 + h1 , where the LOS component h1 is composed of i.i.d Nakagami-m random variables and the entries of the scattering component h1 follow the i.i.d Rayleigh fading distribution [28]. According to [29], by using the inverse Laplace transform of the MGF, a well-approximated expression for the probability density function (PDF) and cumulative distributiuon function (CDF) of γ 1 = γ1 h 1 2 F are, respectively, given by

IV. PERFORMANCE ANALYSIS In this section, by using the method of Meijer-G functions, we derive analytical expressions for the ergodic capacity, OP, and ASER of the considered HSTRN.

div.head: A. Ergodic Capacity
div.p: The average ergodic capacity is defined as the expected value of the instantaneous mutual information of the end-toend SINR, namely
div.formula: C erg = 1 2 E [log 2 (1 + γ d )] , (13

B. Outage Probability
div.p: The OP is an important quality-of-service (QoS) measure in wireless systems and is defined as the probability that the output instantaneous SNR γ d falls below an acceptable SNR threshold γ th , namely, [7]- [8]
div.formula: Pr (γ d ≤ γ th ) = F γ d (γ th ) . (25

div.head: C. Average Symbol Error Rate

For M -PAM signals, the ASER can be calculated as [34]

div.p: Remark 2. While the ASER expressions derived above are approximate, our computer simulations in Section IV will demonstrate that they provide sufficient accuracy.

div.head: D. Asymptotic Analysis at High SNR
div.p: In this section, we provide an asymptotic analysis at high SNR in terms of diversity order and array gain in order to gain further insights into the considered network.
Inspired by [14] and [29], we use the series representation of Meijer-G function given by [36, eq. ( 9.303)]
div.formula: G m,n p,q x a 1 , . . . , a p b 1 , . . . , b q = m h=1 m j=1,j =h Γ b j -b h n j=1 Γ 1 -b h -a j q j=m+1 Γ 1 + b h -b j p j=n+1 Γ a j -b h x b h × p F q 1 + b h -a 1 , . . . , 1 + b h -a p ; 1 + b h -b 1 , . . . , 1 + b h -b q ; (-1) p-m-n x , (49
div.p: where in the case of x → 0, p F q (; ;) has the property [37] p F q a 1 , . . . , a p ; b 1 , . . . , b q ; x → 1.
With this result, the asymptotic CDF of Γ 1 can be expressed as
div.formula: F ∞ Γ1 (x) = α Ns c l=0 c l β c-l I1 i=1 η i γ3,i x γ1 d-l . (51)
div.p: Since the asymptotic performance of F ∞ Γ1 (x) is determined by the lowest order terms of γ1 at high SNR, we let l = c in (51), and further obtain
div.formula: F ∞ Γ1 (x) = α N s I1 i=1 ρ i γ3,i x γ1 N s + O x N s +1 , (52
div.p: where O (•) stands for higher order terms. Meanwhile, as with F ∞ γ2 (x), by applying the Maclaurin series representation of the exponential function to (8), one can obtain
div.formula: F ∞ γ2 (x) = 1 N d ! x γ2 N d + O x N d +1 . (53
div.p: Hence, by using (53) and (11) along with [26, eq. (3.351.3)], the CDF of Γ 2 in (29) at high SNR is given by
div.formula: F ∞ Γ2 (x) = 1 γN d 2 I2 j=1 ω j γN d 4,j x N d + O x N d +1 . (54
div.p: Finally, substituting (52) and ( 54) into ( 27) yields the F ∞ γup (x) as ( 55).

In what follows, we consider the asymptotic behavior of the ASER in the high SNR regime. To this end, we first denote γ1 = η 1 γ and γ2 = η 2 γ, and substitute (55) into (21). After some mathematical manipulations, one can obtain (56)
Then, by employing (56) in (35), the asymptotic ASER expression with respect to the diversity order and array gain can be obtained as [38]
div.formula: P ∞ s = (G a γ) -G d + O γ-(G d +1) , (57
div.p: where the diversity order and array gain are given by
div.formula: G d = min (N s , N d ) , (58

div.p: and
div.formula: Ns (N s < N d ) Ξ (a, b, θ) α Neq I1 i=1 ρ i γ3,i η1 Neq + 1 Neq!η Neq 2 (N s = N d = N eq ) Ξ (a, b, θ) I2 j=1 ω j γ4,j η2 N d (N d < N s )(59)
div.p: where Ξ (a, b, θ) is determined by the modulation formats, which will be described below.

div.head: 1) M-PAM:
div.p: In the case of M-PAM modulation, Ξ (a, b, θ) can be written as
div.formula: Ξ (a, b, θ) = 2 (M -1)/πM 3 (M 2 -1) 2G d π/2 0 (sin φ) 2G d dφ. (60
div.p: By using [26, eq. (3.621.3)] and [38, eq. ( 6.1.49)], (60) can be rewritten as
2) M-PSK: For M -PSK modulation, Ξ (a, b, θ) can be expressed as
div.formula: Ξ (a, b, θ) = 1 (sin (π/M )) 2G d π-π/M 0 (sin φ) 2G d dφ. (62)
div.p: Applying [26, eq. (3.621.
3)] and [37, eq. ( 6.1.49)] along with the symmetry and periodicity of the sine function, we can obtain
div.formula: Ξ (a, b, θ) = 1 (sin (π/M )) 2N π/2 0 (sin φ) 2G d dφ + π/2 π/M (sin φ) 2G d dφ = 1 πsin 2G d (π/M ) √ πΓ (G d + 1/2) 2Γ (G d ) + cos π M × 2 F 1 1 2 , -G d - 1 2 ; 3 2 ; cos 2 π M ,(63)
div.p: where 2 F 1 (a, b; c; z) denotes the Gauss hypergeometric function [26].
3) M-QAM: Similar to the procedure used in deriving (63), Ξ (a, b, θ) for M -QAM modulation is given by
div.formula: Ξ (a, b, θ)= 4 π 1 √ M - 1 M M -1 3 2G d π/2 0 (sin φ) 2G d dφ + 4 π 1- 1 √ M 2 M -1 3 2G d π/2 π/4 (sin φ) 2G d dφ = 4 π 1 √ M - 1 M M -13
div.p: Remark 3. It is revealed in (58) that the maximal achievable diversity order of the considered HSTRN equals the minimum of the number of the antennas deployed at the source and destination. Moreover, it can also be observed from (59) that although CCI does not affect the system diversity order, it does degrade the performance of the HSTRN by reducing the array gain.

V. NUMERICAL RESULTS This section presents computer simulations to confirm the validity of our analytical results and investigates the impact of the system parameters on the performance of the considered HSTRN. In the simulations, the satellite-relay link is subject to Shadowed-Rician fading with channel parameters given in Table I, and the relay-destination link follows a Rayleigh fading distribution. Similar to most of the related work in this area, we consider η 1 = η 2 = 1, namely, γ1 = γ2 = γ, and equal total-CCI power at the relay and destination, namely, I1 i=1 γ3,i = I2 j=1 γ4,j = γtot . In addition, the label (N s , N d ) denotes the number of antennas at the source and destination, respectively, and all the simulations are obtained by performing 10 7 channel realizations.

Fig. 2 shows the ergodic capacity of the HSTRN for different antenna configurations, where the satellite-relay link undergoes average shadowing (AS) and I 1 = I 2 = 1 with γtot = 1dB. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that the proposed analytical results are in good agreement with the simulation results, implying that the proposed expressions can accurately evaluate the ergodic capacity of the considered system. As expected, the ergodic capacity improves with an increase in the number of antennas, demonstrating the benefits of employing multiple antennas and beamforming in HSTRNs. For example, the antenna configuration with (N s , N d ) = (4, 4) can achieve a capacity enhancement of approximate 1 bit/s/Hz compared with (N s , N d ) = (2, 2) at γ = 30dB. Fig. 3 shows the impact of different CCI powers on the ergodic capacity of the HSTRN for the other fading cases, namely, frequent heavy shadowing (FHS) and infrequent light shadowing (ILS). Here, we assume (N s , N d ) = (4, 4), γtot = {-∞, 1, 3}dB with γtot = -∞dB denote the case of no CCI, and I 1 = I 2 = 2 with γ3,1 = 2γ 3,2 and γ4,1 = 2γ 4,2 . It can be seen from Fig. 3 that for both the FHS and ILS scenarios, an increase in the CCI power causes noticeable degradation of the system capacity. However, as the CCI power increases, the capacity gap between FHS and ILS becomes smaller, which indicates that in the presence of strong interference, the ergodic capacity is not sensitive to the shadowing conditions. Fig. 4 illustrates the OP of HSTRN with different antenna configurations for the threshold γ th = 3dB and I 1 = I 2 = 1 with γtot = 1dB. The curves for the analytical OP and the asymptotic OP are calculated by (34) and (55), respectively. As illustrated, an excellent agreement between the simulation and analytical results can be seen, and the analytical curve is sufficiently tight across the entire SNR range of interest, while the asymptotic curves match well with the exact curves at high SNR. In addition, increasing the number of antennas at the source and/or destination significantly improves the system OP. Moreover, it can be clearly seen that the achievable diversity order of the considered system is equal to the minimum number of antennas deployed at the source or destination, min (N s , N d ). For example, the diversity order is two for the configurations (N s , N d ) = (4, 2) and (N s , N d ) = (2, 4), and close to the simulation results in the high SNR regime. The asymptotic ASER curves in (57) are also plotted to provide further insights into the diversity order and array gain under different antenna configurations. As in the case of OP, it can be seen that the more antennas that are employed at the source and/or destination, the better the system performance that can be achieved. Moreover, it can be observed that the configuration with (N s , N d ) = (4, 2) exhibits a better ASER performance than that with (N s , N d ) = (2,4), which indicates that antennas employed at the source provide a greater influence on system performance than antennas at the destination. This is due to the fact that, by employing the AF protocol, the SINR of the S-R link is amplified by the relay node. This observation also suggests that if the total available number of antennas is fixed, more antennas should be deployed at the source.

Fig. 6 plots the ASER curves for different CCI powers assuming BPSK modulation, where the simulation parameters are set to be the same as Fig. 2. Similar to the case of ergodic capacity, ASER performance degrades significantly with an increase in CCI power. When the CCI power increases from -∞ to 3dB, significant performance degradation occurs although the diversity order of the network remains at four. This is because the CCI causes a loss of array gain. Furthermore, comparing the ASER for the FHS and AS scenarios, although the AS case yields better performance than the FHS case, the better channel quality does not offer an increase in diversity order. However, it does improve the system performance by providing extra array gain.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, we have investigated the performance of a multiple antenna hybrid satellite-terrestrial relay network with multiple co-channel interferes at both the terrestrial relay and destination. Specifically, we have derived an approximate closed-form expression for the ergodic capacity of the considered network, and we have obtained analytical expressions for OP and ASER that are very tight except for small deviations in the low SNR regime. In addition, we have also provided simple asymptotic formulas for the high SNR regime, which enable the characterization of various system parameters on the achievable diversity order and array gain of the network.

Simulations have been provided to confirm the validity of the theoretical analysis, and indicate the impact of key system parameters such as number of antennas, channel coefficients and CCI power on system performance. It has been found that although the maximal diversity order of min (N s , N d ) can be achieved, the CCI severely degrades the performance of the HSTRN by reducing the array gain.

div.p: This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grants 61271255, 61471392, 61571115 and 61501507, the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province under Grant BK20131068, and the Open Research Fund of National Mobile Communications Research Laboratory in Southeast University (No. 2012D15).

Min Lin (M'13) received the B.S. degree from National University of Defense Technology, the M.S. degree from Nanjing Institute of Communication Engineering, and Ph.D. degree from Southeast University in 1993University in , 2000University in , and 2008, respectively, all in electrical engineering. He is presently an Associate Professor of Southeast University, and also an Adjunct Professor of PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China. His current research interests include wireless communications and array signal processing. He is the author or coauthor of more than 80 papers, and holds 4 patents. Dr. Lin is a Senior Member of Chinese Institute of Electronics (CIE).
